Award.AwardTitle: Gromov-Witten and Donaldson-Thomas theories in dimensions two and three
Award.AbstractNarration:
String theory, a branch of physics, predicts that the building blocks of spacetime (which is the fabric of the universe) are certain geometric objects called Calabi-Yau manifolds. The PI will focus on the investigation of the geometric properties of these spaces, mainly by computing important invariants associated to them, called Gromov-Witten and Donaldson-Thomas invariants. Both Gromov-Witten (GW) and Donaldson-Thomas (DT) theories are inspired by theoretical physics and involve several mathematical subjects, including geometry, topology, algebra, combinatorics, and representation theory. The principal investigator will continue his research on the curious conjectural correspondences between GW and DT theories and will try to discover their links to these branches of mathematics and physics. The investigator plans to use the framework provided by these disciplines to create and teach courses for and mentor high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral researchers.

More specifically, the principal investigator will investigate the DT invariants of 2-dimensional sheaves in Calabi-Yau threefolds inspired by "M5-brane elliptic genera" and "BPS invariants of D4-D2-D0 systems" studied by string theorists. The PI plans to prove 1) the modularity of these DT invariants and 2) find their relation to the "BPS invariants of D6-D2-D0 systems" predicted from dualities in string theory. The latter BPS invariants are manifested in DT invariants of 1-dimensional sheaves as well as in GW invariants. The PI also plans to develop an algorithm for computing the rank 2 DT invariants of toric threefolds and then study their properties. This is known as the "Topological Vertex Algorithm" and has been a very powerful tool for computing GW and rank 1 DT invariants of the toric threefolds. The advanced tools that will be employed for these projects are localization, deformation, degeneration, categorification, wall-crossing, and mirror symmetry techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had two main objectives:

  1. Study the properties of the Donaldson-Thomas invariants of torsion 2-dimensional sheaves in threefolds. 
  2. Study the properties of the Donaldson-Thomas invariatns of higher rank torsion free sheaves in surfaces and threefolds.

The first type invariants are mathematical analogs of the invariants studied by the physicists counting D4-D2-D0 BPS states. The S-duality conjecture in physics predicts that such invariants have modular porperties. Modularity property is a very powerful tool as it allows to determine infinitely many DT invariants by just knowing a small number of them.

The scond type invariants are direct generalizations of the famous rank 1 Donaldson-Thomas invraints introduced by Maulik-Nekrasov-Okounkov-Pandharipande. Rank 1 DT invariants are conjecturally related to Gromov-Witten invariants. An important case for which this conjecture is fully proven is the case of toric threefolds. And the proof is by means of the so called topological vertex developed for both Gromov-Witteh and the rank 1 Donaldson-Thomas theories. The PI has developed a topological vertex for evaluating the rank 2 Donaldson-Thomas invariants of toric threefolds (paper 6 below).

This project has produced the following publications and preprints:

1) (With R. P. Thomas) Degeneracy loci, virtual cycles and nested Hilbert schemes. 33 pages. arXiv:1709.06105, 2017. 

2) (With M. Kool) Higher rank sheaves on threefolds and functional equations. 33 pages. arXiv:1706.05246, 2017.

3) (With A. Sheshmani and S.-T. Yau) Localized Donaldson-Thomas theory of surfaces. 28 pages. arXiv:1701.08902, 2017.

4) (With A. Sheshmani and S.-T. Yau) Nested Hilbert schemes on surfaces: Virtual fundamental class. 47 pages. arXiv:1701.08899, 2017. 

 5) (With M. Kool) Rank 2 wall-crossing and the Serre correspondence. Selecta Math., 23(2017):1599–1617, arXiv:1602.03113.

 6) (With M. Kool and B. Young) Rank 2 sheaves on toric 3-folds: classical and virtual counts. 59 pages. To be published in Int. Math. Res. Not. IMRN, arXiv:1509.03536.

 7) (With A. Sheshmani) Intersection numbers on the relative Hilbert schemes of points on surfaces. Asian J. Math., 21(2016):531–542, arXiv:1504.01107.

 8) (With A. Sheshmani) Generalized Donaldson-Thomas Invariants of 2-Dimensional sheaves on local P2. Advances in Theoretical and Mathematical Physics. 19 (2015), No. 3, 673–699, arXiv:1309.0056.

 9) (With A. Sheshmani and R. P. Thomas) Counting curves on surfaces in Calabi-Yau 3-folds. Math. Ann. 360 (2014), 67–78, arXiv:1309.0051.

 10) (With A. Sheshmani) Donaldson-Thomas invariants of 2-Dimensional sheaves inside threefolds and modular forms. 29 pages. arXiv:1309.0050. To be published in Advances in Mathematics.

 11) (With A. Sheshmani and Y. Toda) Stable pairs on nodal K3 fibrations. 37 pages. To be published in Int. Math. Res. Not. IMRN, arXiv:1308.4722.

12) (With M. Kool) Stable reflexive sheaves and localization. J. Pure Appl. Algebra, 221(2017):1934–1954, arXiv:1308.3688.

13) (With D. Karp and S. Payne) Cremona symmetry in Gromov-Witten theory. Pro Math- ematica. XXIX 57 (2016) 129–149, arXiv:1412.1516.

14) (With Y. Jiang and M. Kool) Toric sheaves on weighted projective planes. 48 pages and 10 figures. To be published in Advances in Theoretical and Mathematical Physics, arXiv:1209.3922. 

Papers 1), 4), 7) are the PI's contributions to the Hilbert schemes and the invariant of general surfaces. Paper 1) will have other applications in construction of virtual fundamental classes in situations other than Hilbert schemes.

Papers 2), 5), 6), 12) are the PI's contributions to the theory of higher rank torsion free sheaves on threefolds and their invariants that are in the direction of the second goal of the porject mentoned above. Paper 2) gives the first general structure result on the invariants of higher rank torsion free sheaves on threefolds.

Papers 3), 8)--11) are PI's  contributions to the theory of torsion sheaves on threefolds and their invariants. In paper 8), the DT invariants of torsion 2d sheaves in local CP^2 are computed by localization and wall-crossing techniques and verify the integrality conjecture of Joyce-Song for some of these invariants. In paper 9), the DT invariants of torsion 2d sheaves in threefolds are related to curve counting invariants of MNOP and formulate precisely the physical S-duality conjecture in physics in terms of these invariants. Paper 10) proves the S-duality conjecture for certain DT invariants of K3 fibrations over curves. Paper 11) obtains an explicit wall-crossing formula for the DT invariant of semistable 2d sheaves and the PT invariants supported on fibers of K3 fibrations over a curve. This is motivated by and has application to T-duality in physics.

Paper 13) uses Cremona symmetry in birational geometry and degeneration techniques to compute certain GW invariants. As an application, a classical fact regarding the count of rational curves in a projective spaces is reproved by means of this new method. Paper 14) obtains a combinatorial description of higher rank toric torsion free sheaves on weighted projective planes. As an application, the modularity predicted by S-duality is obtained in certain cases in terms of the generating series of the Hurwitz class numbers.
